document.docAuthor: Zeppelini, Douglas & Lima, Estevam Cipriano Araujo De
document.docTitle: Tyrannoseira gladiata Zeppelini & Lima, 2012, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Tyrannoseira (Collembola, Entomobryidae, Seirini) from Paraiba, Northeastern Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Tyrannoseira (Collembola, Entomobryidae, Seirini) from Paraiba, Northeastern Brazil

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material. Brazil :
Paraíba, Araruna, State Park Pedra da Boca,
21 .V. 2011
, D. D. Silva Coll., holotype male, 11 paratypes (
3 male
,
8 female
) same data as Holotype , deposited at Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (CM/ MNRJ # 2294 ).
Etymology. The species was named as reference to the shape of the spine-like setae on first tibiotarsus of adult males, which resemble the ancient roman sword.

Description. Total length of holotype 2.1 mm , body measures shown in
Table 1
. Habitus typical entomobryid (
Fig. 1
). Color in alcohol, dark brown all over head, body and coxae, eye patches darker. Legs, furca, Ant I and basal halves of Ant. II–IV whitish yellow (
Fig. 1
). Brownish rounded scales covering head, thorax, abdomen, legs, antennal segments I and II, and basal half of Ant. III, no scales on Ant. IV. Ventral tube without scales.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Length of the body segments of the holotype, antenna and head of
Tyrannoseira gladiata
sp. nov.
Abd—abdominal segment, Ant—antennal segment, CD – cephalic diagonal. Measures given in μm.

FIGURES 1–2.
Tyrannoseira gladiata
sp. nov.
: 1, habitus and color pattern in alcohol; 2, apical bulb on fourth antennal segment.

FIGURES 3–4.
Tyrannoseira gladiata
sp. nov.
: 3, right eye patch; 4, labial triangle.

FIGURES 5–11.
Tyrannoseira gladiata
sp. nov.
: 5, right femur of an adult male; 6, right tibiotarsus of an adult male; 7, trochanteral organ; 8, first foot complex; 9, second foot complex; 10, third foot complex; 11, apex of dens and mucro.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Prothoracic femur in males strongly broadened, bearing 13 or more stout spines ( Figs. 5 ,
12- 14
). Prothoracic tibiotarsus in males slender, curved at base, obliquely articulated to femur, bearing one row of 11–13 elongated spine-like setae ( Figs 6 , 12, 15, 16 ). Trochanteral organ formed by 16 short setae (
Fig. 7
). All ungues with four inner teeth, basal teeth paired, two unpaired distal teeth (
Fig. 8–10
), and with a dorsal tooth on the basal external lamella. Unguiculi lanceolate (
Figs 8–10
), inner lamella of hind unguiculi with small teeth or weakly serrate. Tenent hair flat, capitate and smooth. Venter of manubrium with 5 + 5 subapical ciliated setae on a transversal line. Manubrium without spine-like setae. Mucro falcate, without basal spine (
Fig. 11
). No macrochaeta on first abdominal segment of adults, dorsal macrochaetae of head and body distributed as shown in
Fig. 17
. Chaetotaxy of the trichobothrial region of Abd. II and III shown in
Figure 18
. Other characters are listed in
Table 2
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 12–16.
Tyrannoseira gladiata
sp. nov.
: 12, first leg of an adult male (right); 13, femur of first leg; 14, detail of femoral spines of an adult male; 15, first tibiotarsus; 16, tibiotarsal spine.

FIGURE 17.
Tyrannoseira gladiata
sp. nov.
: pattern of distribution of macrochaetae on head and body, compared to other species of the genus.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
T. gladiata
sp. nov.
can be differentiated by the Ant/CD ratio ( 2.9 ), which is the highest among the five described species (
Table 2
), the presence of only two macrochaetae on region A (
Christiansen & Bellinger 2000
) of Abd. II, the antenna almost as long as the body length, the chaetotaxy of the fields 5 and 6 on posterior dorsal head, 16 setae on metatrochanteral organ and the color pattern. The new species resembles T. diabolica
Bellini & Godeiro, 2012
in the number of ventral setae on the manubrial apex.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 18.
Tyrannoseira gladiata
sp. nov.
: chaetotaxy of abdominal segments II (left) and III (right). Black circles––pseudopores, open circles––broad ciliated macrochaetae, lines––microchaetae. Arrows indicate head and lateral direction from the middle line.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Four species of the genus
Seira
are included in
Table 2
for comparison,
S. mirianae
Arlé & Guimarães 1981
,
S. yemensis
Barra 2004
,
S. andensis
Jacquemart 1980
because they share the absence of macrochaetae on Abd. I and
S. mantis
Zeppelini & Bellini 2006
because of its sexual dimorphism. The species T. raptora , T. bicolorcornuta (
Bellini et al. 2009
), T. sex
Bellini & Zeppelini 2011
and T. diabolica are also compared.
